title: Rowton, Cheshire
text:
Rowton is a village and <a href="civil%20parishes%20in%20England">civil parish</a> on the outskirts of <a href="Chester">Chester</a>, in the <a href="unitary%20authority">unitary authority</a> of <a href="Cheshire%20West%20and%20Chester">Cheshire West and Chester</a> and ceremonial county of <a href="Cheshire">Cheshire</a>, England. It is located between <a href="Christleton">Christleton</a> and <a href="Waverton%2C%20Cheshire">Waverton</a>, near the <a href="A41%20road">A41 road</a>. The <a href="Rowton%20Hall">Rowton Hall</a> hotel is the most prominent landmark in the village. At the <a href="2001%20United%20Kingdom%20census">2001 census</a> Rowton had a population of 497, 
decreasing to 441 in the <a href="2011%20United%20Kingdom%20census">2011 census</a>.
The <a href="Battle%20of%20Rowton%20Heath">Battle of Rowton Heath</a> took place in the village on 24 September 1645 during the <a href="First%20English%20Civil%20War">English Civil War</a>. It resulted in a decisive <a href="roundhead">Parliamentarian</a> victory over a <a href="Cavalier">Royalist</a> army commanded in person by <a href="Charles%20I%20of%20England">Charles I</a>. 
Rowton was previously a township in <a href="Christleton">Christleton</a> parish of <a href="Hundreds%20of%20Cheshire">Broxton Hundred</a>, becoming a civil parish in 1866. Its population was recorded at 88 in 1801, 122 in 1851, 205 in 1901 and 228 in 1951.
